summary.p: Humanistic collection, chiefly of Latin poems, many dedicated to Alfano Alfani of Perugia ; interspersed with transcripts of Latin inscriptions and with later additions.

msContents.textLang: Latin with some Italian and Greek

msItem.note: The first leaf, which is missing, probably contained the beginning of Francesco Maturanzio 's translation of Moscus' ‘Amor fugitivus’, preceded by a dedicatory letter to Alfano Alfani, since the last 13 lines are the first piece on fol.2. It is pr. G. Conestabili, Memorie di Alfano Alfani, Perugia, 1848, pp.97–9. This item and nos. 2–101 at least are also found in MS. Perugia Bibl. Comunale C.61, on which see Mazzatinti, Inv. delle Bibl. d'Italia, 5, pp. 96–7; A. Perosa in Studi in onore U. Paoli, Florence, 1954, pp. 549–51; Mostra del Poliziano, Florence, 1955, pp. 108–9. The main hand of our MS. is the same as that of the Perugia MS.

msItem.rubric: E Greco Moschi Idem Amor fugitiuus
msItem.incipit: Cum Venus intento
msItem.note: pr. I. del Lungo, Prose volgari inedite e poesie latine e greche edite e inedite di Ang. Ambrogini Poliziano, Florence, 1867, p.526

msItem.rubric: In violas a venere sua acceptas
msItem.note: pr. del Lungo, op.cit., p.233–4

msItem.rubric: Disticon ad quandam puellȩ pulcherrimȩ Imaginem
msItem.incipit: Vidit ut hanc livor faciem si carpex non est
msItem.note: Also on fol.118v: ‘In puellam’. One of the ‘desiderata’ listed by del Lungo, op.cit., p.555. First printed, from this MS., by Perosa, op.cit., p.550
pr. del Lungo p.154–5
pr. del Lungo p.545
pr. del Lungo pp.268–71. l.63 missing in MS.
pr. del Lungo p.271–2

msItem.incipit: Summe ducum specimen magni Mauortis alumne
msItem.explicit: Effodit sacros nobis de monte liquores. / Finis./ Quȩ petis eue tibi Saraceni Carmina trado / Que peto ni tradas: tu Saracenus eris.
msItem.note: It is an acrostic on ‘Salue Hercules Dux Magne’

msItem.incipit: Vultu quȩ totiens me premis aspero

msItem.note: (Francesco Gonzaga, cr.1461, d.1483)
msItem.incipit: O foelix cauea o beatiores

msItem.rubric: F. Mataratius de obitu P. Marsi Poet
msItem.incipit: Este procul Lauri tristes et plectra lyreque
msItem.note: pr. V. Bini, Memorie storiche della Perugina Università, Perugia 1816, p.576.

msItem.incipit: Quam bene Xystina haec: quae prope fluminis undas
Obstruxit Dominam temerariam porticus urbem

msItem.rubric: In bibliotheca a Xysto Pon. Instaurata
msItem.incipit: Templa: domum expositis: uicos: fora: moenia: pontes
msItem.note: See S. Bissolati, Vite di Due Illustri Cremonesi, Milan 1856, p.81

msItem.author: ‘Cardinalis Papiensis’ [Jacopo Ammanati, Card. of Pavia 1461–79]
msItem.incipit: Trans amnem ut uisus Lepus est: tum tenditur arcus

msItem.author: ‘Cardinalis Papiensis’ [Jacopo Ammanati, Card. of Pavia 1461–79]
msItem.incipit: Luca ortu: Sena lege fuit mihi patria: nomen.
msItem.note: From the Cardinal's will, pr. in his Epist. et Commentarii, 1506, fol.336v.
[the assassin of Duke Galeazzo Maria Sforza of Milan in 1476]
msItem.incipit: Quisquis audet iusta crudeles morte tyrannos

msItem.note: Distich
msItem.incipit: Immemorem qui te dicit line: fallitur: errat
Sanguine si Princeps Adamas corrumpitur hyrci
msItem.note: In MS. Estense 681, autograph of Tebaldeo's poems, fol.6. See S.Pasquazi ‘Il Tebaldeo Latino’ in his Rinascimento Ferrarese, Rome, 1957, p.119

msItem.incipit: D.M. / Quid sibi volt queris Tellus congesta viator
msItem.note: ed. P. Burmannus, Anthol. Vet. Lat. II, 1773, p.161

msItem.incipit: Est breue quod petii: modicum minimumque: parumque
Olim ego Tursiano frondens altissima campo
Foelix hinc pete Romuli penates
Menia Cȩropidum phama est coluisse Mineruam
Restabat tandem misero sors improba vati
msItem.note: Simone Bonadies was created bishop of Imola 1488, trans. to Rimini 1511, d.1518

msItem.incipit: Hac Gemini antistes iuris tumulatus in urna est
Principium linguis qui das Alphane disertis
Parcite iam pueri semper Scaramella canentes
msItem.note: pr. in Epigrammata Cantalycii et Aliquorum Discipulorum Eius, Venice, 1493

msItem.rubric: Quercus alloquitur Cardinalis (sic) Sancti Petri ad Vincula
msItem.note: [probably Giuliano della Rovere, cr.1471, the future pope Julius II]
msItem.incipit: Aurate merito frondes mihi: et aurea poma
Ante domi Letum dulces aluere camen
msItem.note: pr. Vermiglioli, Memorie di F. Maturanzio, Perugia, 1807, pp.121–3

msItem.incipit: Iuppiter iratus nimium Iunone sinistra
Patria conspiciet reducem te Liuia: Phoebus
Fax data pectoribus nostris heu parcuis ure

msItem.title: L. Montagna ad Laurentium [Zane]
msItem.incipit: Fronde velut Laurus: quoniam virtute virescis
msItem.note: pr. G. Fatini in Giorn. Stor. Lett. Ital. 74, 1919, p.234n. from MS.Perugia C.61, fol.11

msItem.title: Epitaphium Turcorum Imperatoris Invictissimi
msItem.incipit: Qui uici innumeros populos tot regna: tot urbes
msItem.note: WIC 15730a. Also in MSS. Milan Ambros. Trotti 373, fol.53v - see Sabbadini, Classici e Umanisti da Codd. Ambros., 1933, pp.13–14 and Vat. Urb. Lat.1166, fol.1. Probably on the Sultan Mahomet II, d.1481.

msItem.rubric: F. Mataratius : Ad F. Varanensem Camertem Antistitem
msItem.note: [Fabrizie da Varano, Bishop of Camerino 1482–1508]
msItem.incipit: Antistes populi decus Camertis

msItem.rubric: Elegia F. Zambicarii pro Alphano ad Franciscum
msItem.incipit: Quod tellus: quod et unda negat temtabo volatu

msItem.author: F. Mataratius
msItem.incipit: Ante meos Laurum subito quae nata penates

msItem.rubric: Bernardinus Capella et Gaspar Manius: ad Cardinalem S. Georgii
msItem.note: [Raffaele Riario cr. 1477 d.1521]
msItem.incipit: Versus dum legis hos parum disertos

msItem.rubric: Egloga. Interloquutores Bernardinus Capella et Gaspar Manius. Alter sub nomine Almonis. Alter uero sub nomine Tiberini’ beg: , ends: .
msItem.incipit: Quid sub nixa velit mento Tiberine sinistra
msItem.explicit: Plaudite gaudentes letique valete Quirites. / Finis Bucholicae
msItem.note: These verses, preceded by a prose preface to the Cardinal, are in MS.B.M.Harl.4088, fol.13v–18: see R. Weiss in Italia Medioevale e Umanistica II, 1959, p.361.

msItem.rubric: F[abritius Varanus] Camers pontifex in Georgium Spretum
msItem.incipit: Te tibi ve, extremem video perusina ruinam
msItem.note: Pr., with variants, G. B. Vermiglioli, Memorie di Jac. Antiquari, Perugia, 1813, pp.342–3

msItem.incipit: Stella Maris feruentis aue, pietatis alumna
Legibus est finis nullus: mihi nulla laboris
Foelices Iani sonnos(sic): qui forte puellam
Innumere spumant pleno de pectore leges
Me reuocat legis studium: sum mense decembri
Exemptem media de Pallados ęgide dicas
Ipse quod es: Lector: fuimus nos: tu quoque fies
Dic rogo te Thyphis quoties symplegades intrat
Vela cadunt, agimus remis ego pronus et hęrens
Venerat ursus, aper, Patauii chimentus ad urbem
Quae minus arrecta flaccent animalia cauda
Psitacus humanas sollers effingere voces

msItem.rubric: Epitaphium Bernardi Portii in Templo Mineru
msItem.incipit: Portius hic puer est, tota defletus ab urbe

msItem.author: ‘Panthagatus’ [the name, in Pomponio Leto's Academy, of Giovanbattista Capranica, bishop of Fermo 1478–84]
msItem.title: Poems

msItem.incipit: Tempore si nostro debetur gloria furtis
msItem.note: Clearly against Cardinal Pietro Riario, Patriarch of Constantinople 1472–4: the poem names him ‘Petrus’

msItem.incipit: Florat Saluiatus Petrum: Tirrhesia et Agnus
msItem.note: A satire left on the tomb of Cardinal Pietro Riario. See Luzio in Giorn. Stor. Lett. Ital. cit., 19, 1892, p.89

msItem.incipit: Quodque rapax paulus per septem condidit annos
Nate adamante puer: spes sola Alphane tuorum
msItem.note: pr. Conestabili, op.cit., p.100

msItem.incipit: Profer marmoreum speciosa Nocentia pectus
Phebus amat: gratiorque deus dat vulnera Daphne

msItem.rubric: Epigrammata comperta in agro veneto super urnam fictilem in qua erant ampulle binae: liquoris pretiossissimi ut creditur plenȩ
msItem.incipit: Plutoni sacrum munus: ne attingite fures
msItem.note: Listed under Falsae in C.I.L. V.194*, as from Este. The earliest date given for the discovery is 1498. The ampullae apparently came later into the possession of Francesco Maturanzio - see Scardeone, De Antiq. Urbis Patav., Basle, 1560, pp.55–6; Vermiglioli, Mem. di F.M., cit., p.52.

msItem.incipit: Ut belli sonuere tubę violenta peremit
msItem.note: See WIC 19768

msItem.rubric: Xyterii Sidonii oratoris antiqui de pastoribus
msItem.incipit: Almo: Theon: Thyrsis: orti sub colle pelori
Trax puer astricto Glacie dum ludit in Hebro
Si tibi forma data est: quamuis dare numina possint
msItem.note: pr. J. Oeschger, Pontani Carmina, 1948, p.454 as a work of Pontano

msItem.incipit: Dilacerare pium potuit soror impia fratrem
Hic tegor expositus furtim miserabilis infans

msItem.rubric: F[abricius Varanus] Camers Pont. In Laudem Cantalyci qui Iuvenalem Commentatus est
msItem.incipit: I nunc perfacilis legi Poeta.
Cum mea me genitrix gravida gestaret in aluo

msItem.rubric: Epigramma quod aiunt inscriptum quondam Theatro Romae
msItem.incipit: Postquam potentes nec verentes sumptum
msItem.note: Ausonius , XX.35–41, in same corrupt version as in Florence, Bibl. Laur. Ashb. 1732, which has a similar heading (identified by M.D.Reeve)

msItem.rubric: In Plebe oppidi Montoni in marmore
msItem.incipit: D.M./C.IVLIO.C.F. CLV. PROCULO. TIFER/NIS

msItem.rubric: In palatio Capitanei Perusi in Marmore
msItem.incipit: DIVO ANTONINO. /.PIO./.C.EGNATIVS
msItem.note: C.I.L. XI. 1924 - MS.Perugia C.61 is cited

msItem.incipit: TIBI DEAE. BONAE. VNA.QVAE

msItem.rubric: F. Maturantii Genethliacum Carmen in recens natum Iohanni Mari Aureolo filiolum. Amico incomparabili
msItem.incipit: Quid cessas mea Calliope: quid munera differs

msItem.rubric: F. Varani Camertis Pon. Genethliaticum in recens natum Gaspari Camerti poet.AMICO. CHAR.
msItem.incipit: Quid cessas mea Musa? quid moraris
Cum foderet gladio castum Lucretia pectus

msItem.rubric: (fol.28v) Hoc repertum fragmentum est in quodam codice vetustissimo: satis tamen mendoso ut cernere licet. Faxit deus ut opus integrum aliquando in lucem redeat
(fol.29) Remii Fannii Grammatici de ponderibus et mensuris libellus
msItem.incipit: Pondera peoniis veterum memorata libellis
msItem.explicit: Nec non et sine aquis. /Hic deficit
msItem.note: ll.1–163 of Baehrens, Poetae Lat. Min. IV, no.46, where other MSS. containing only 11.1–163 are cited. Walther, in Alphab. Verzeichnis no.14226, cites further MSS.

msItem.rubric: Epitaphium uxoris Boetii per eam conditum
msItem.incipit: Elpes dicta fui siculȩ regionis alumna
msItem.note: Walther, Alphab. Verzeichnis, nos.5352 and 7695

msItem.rubric: Epigramma antiquum in eos qui docent aves loqui: aut auium voces imitantur
msItem.incipit: Xeno loqui picas docet: Andreemo philomelas
Vos equidem o pueri celestia regna videtis
msItem.note: A version of WIC 20804

msItem.incipit: Nomina septenum sapientum Graecia cantat
msItem.note: WIC 11938. In Epistolario di Guarino Veronese, ed. Sabbadini, II, 1916, p.266. See also Sabbadini, Classici e Umanisti cit., p.11, on MS. Trotti 373 fol. 31v

msItem.incipit: Ante alios castusque et iusti moris amator
Tellus membra sinu condit moribunda platonis

msItem.rubric: Populus Roma. in morte Romuli, his vocibus apud Ennium queritur
msItem.incipit: Romule magne parens, ubi nunc es Romule: dic o
C.IV. Caesar. M.T. Ciceronem ob eius egregias virtutes
msItem.note: An early example of C.I.L. VI.81*

msItem.title: Brief notes on Roman history up to Constantine
msItem.incipit: Troia condita fuit in ętate 111ª post creationem mundi II..D.C.XL.

msItem.title: List of wonders of classical Rome
msItem.incipit: Porte Urbis Romae. Porta Capena quae hodie dicitur porta Sancti pauli
msItem.explicit: Theatrum C. Caesaris hodie domus Cardinalis Sabelli. Sic enim apud Suetonium inveni. Theatrumque summae magnitudinis Tarpeio monti accubans.
msItem.note: Cardinal Giovanbattista Savelli was created 1480, d.1498

msItem.rubric: Quos Affectus Orationis Sequuti Sint Viri Doc.

msItem.incipit: Ego te laudo et admiror
Plutarchus Traiano Discipulo suo S. P. Modestiam tuam
msItem.note: Also in Bodl. MS. Add. C. 139 fol.276v. From the Ps.-Plutarch 's Institutio Traiani, in John of Salisbury 's Policraticus, Book V. See Bertalot on MS. at Parma, in Bibliofilia 38, 1936, p.78

msItem.incipit: P. Cornelius Scipio pater
Historia est testis temporum
Roma sedes senatus

msItem.title: Dates given for the founding of Rome
msItem.incipit: Initium Romae secundum Hieronymum
Romanum igitur imperium
Romulus XVIII annos natus
Sancte frate Hieronyme Consulens de his
Primo fuerunt Romae reges. Ends

msItem.rubric: Supra Pontem Anienis a Narsete constructum
msItem.note: C.I.L. VI. 1199b

msItem.incipit: D.M./ Pauline Valerie. F.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Qui pueri vultis ientacula ludere mecum.
Quae mihi misisti princeps tibi dona remitto
Sacra Ioui fuerat: sed sola oracla tenebat
I mea Calliope doctas ad principis aures
Quae nuper medii turbabat tempora veris
msItem.note: Pr. Vermiglioli, Poesie Inedite di Pacifico Massimo, Perugia 1818, p.125

msItem.incipit: Hic ego sum vatum Genitrix tumulata duorum
msItem.note: pr. Vermiglioli, Mem. di F.M. cit. pp.8–9; Scrittori Perugini II, p.108

msItem.incipit: Quid properas: consiste precor: breue perlege carmen
msItem.note: Pr. Vermiglioli, loc. cit.

msItem.incipit: Dux vigila: placidamque iube procul esse quietem
msItem.note: pr. Vermiglioli, Poesie di P. Massimo cit. pp.126–9. This poem is also in MS.Vat.Urb.Lat.373 fol. 185v–188v

msItem.rubric: Ad formosiss. Adolescentem Epistephidem Coronatum Romanum’
msItem.incipit: Clare Coronati Iuvenis spes magna parentis

msItem.title: Fabula Aesopi Gellio recitata. Sic per Antonium Thebaldeum carminibus mandata
msItem.incipit: Frugibus in mediis foetus cassita fovebat
Socrates Archelai discipulus
msItem.note: Also in MS. Vat. Lat. 8086, fol.4. See A. Campana in ‘Il Poliziano e il suo Tempo’, Atti IV Congr. Internaz. di Studi sul Rinascimento, 1957, p.216

msItem.author: Ermolao Barbaro
msItem.title: ‘Corollari’ to Dioscorides' Pharmacorum
msItem.rubric: Hermolaus Barbarus Patritius Venetus Dioscoridem Medicum e Gręco Latinum reddidit. Cui et totidem addidit capitula ad maiorem auctoris declarationem
msItem.incipit: De Saccaro. Saccarum laudatus ferebat india. fol.49 De Caera. Cęra Graece vocatur Ceros
msItem.note: Chaps.92–3 of Book II, pp.106v–7 in ed. of 1529.
C.I.L. XI.30*

msItem.rubric: Martiani Nimirei Hecatosticum Carmen Ad Christum optimum maximum pro Cardinalis Senensis Salute
msItem.incipit: Christe pater magno terris demissus olympo
msItem.note: The Cardinal of Siena was Francesco Piccolomini, cr.1460, later Pope Pius III.

msItem.incipit: Si potuit quondam chara pro coniuge vates
Claudus habet Venerem. faber: est Vulcanus: habebor

msItem.title: Poems
msItem.note: (by the same?)

msItem.incipit: Vulcani duo sunt; hic Thuscus: Lemnius alter
Frix ardet: dat vela: Helenam rapit: armat Atrides
Conueniunt magnis si distica parva triumphis

msItem.author: Claudian
msItem.title: Carm. Min. XXXII
msItem.rubric: Epigramma ad christum opt. Max. Ausonii: vel Claudiani

msItem.title: Inscription
msItem.rubric: Epigramma antiquum In arcis Pisauri fundamentis inventum
msItem.note: in C.I.L. XI.6435, as from Ferrara

msItem.incipit: Mense pluit toto: Martis spectacula Caesar
msItem.note: pr. Ceschger, Pontani Carmina cit. p.457

msItem.incipit: Laus tua non tua fraus: virtus non copia rerum
Quid levius pluma? pulvis: quid pulvere? ventus
msItem.note: A veriant of WIC 15828–30

msItem.incipit: Nubere cerua cupit sed vult haec nubere ceruis

msItem.title: Inscription
msItem.rubric: Transtiberim in capite pontis Iudeorum est hoc epigramma peruetustum
Illustrium Romanorum epistole quaedam haec sunt. Ex annalibus extracte quas in codice vetustissimo hoc titulo comperi
msItem.incipit: Curius Caesari salutem. Nollem te mirari si ego
msItem.note: On such ‘letters’ see Sabbadini, Le Scoperte dei Codici Latini, I, 1905, p.175. Several of the same letters, from MS. Cesena Malatestiana Plut. Sin. I, 11, pr. in J. M. Muccioli Cat. Codd. MSS. Malat. Cesenatis II, 1780, pp.236–7.

msItem.incipit: Tres Ledam pereunt fratres: Lycus: ornytus: astur
Alphaene o nimium chare et amabilis

msItem.rubric: Bertrando Ministro Aedis Pontificalis ab Concentu Pomponius sal.
msItem.incipit: Petiisti: suavissime amicorum: qui ex illa tua Gallia Romae degunt: Si quȩ de vita Persii haberem

msItem.rubric: Vita Persii Poetae Fabio Persio L. Vitellio Coss.
msItem.incipit: Aulus Persius Flaccus ante Pr. Non. Decembr. Volaterris natus
Quid queris? positum; quę Gens? Quinteria. Nomen?
M. Cato Censorius: qui optimus senator

msItem.rubric: In Basi statuae Q. Fabii Maximi Quae Aretii comperta est
In Basi Statuae C. Marii Aretij

msItem.incipit: D.M./ P. Atilio Rufo
Sex. Valerius Mercurialis augur

msItem.author: ‘F. Camers Pontifex’
msItem.incipit: Me quoties uili tectum ridebis amictu

msItem.author: ‘F. Angelus Spoletinus’
msItem.incipit: Quaenam digna tuos facundia ferret honores?
msItem.note: pr. Conestabile, Mem. di A. Alfani cit. p.100–1

msItem.incipit: O Phoebo Cytharam tendere doctior
Evolat ad summas ventorum flatibus aedes

msItem.author: Caesar
msItem.title: Letters
msItem.note: Four letters, from Cicero , Ep. Ad Att. IX 16; IX 70; IX 13A; IX 14.

msItem.author: Daniel Francinus
msItem.title: Poems
msItem.rubric: Pro Ill. Andriae Principe. F. Bautio

msItem.incipit: Sta: lege quid possit Phoebi memorabile carmen
Ille ego Franciscus Dux Andrius: inclytus haeros
Dux ego progenitus divorum a sanguine regum

msItem.rubric: Fausti Andrelini Poetae Forliuiensis Carmen: Ad Ludovicum Gonzagam Pontificem Mantuanum
msItem.incipit: Nobilis attalico fulget si regia luxu
msItem.note: See no.108b below (fols.149–51)

msItem.incipit: Si mihi centeno resonaret Apolline pectus
msItem.note: The author was probably M. Lucido Fazini , called Fosforo in Leto's Academy, cr. Bishop of Segni in 1482
C.I.L. XI. 1926: MS.Perugia C.61 is cited

msItem.rubric: Epigramma repertum in Ponte S. Angeli Romae: tempore D. Innoc. pp.VIII
msItem.incipit: Pressa tribus dominis uixisti roma superbis

msItem.rubric: Laurens de Nicolactiis Rheatinus Ad Alphaenum Severum
msItem.incipit: Quod tibi pro tanto referam modo munere grates

msItem.rubric: Fratris Baptiste Spagnoli Mantuani Carmelitae ad Falconem Sinibaldum Aegloga: Colloquutores Candidus et Faustulus. Candidus auctoris personam gerit: conqueritur sibi et gregi non esse prosperam fortunam in Latio
msItem.incipit: Faustulus: Candide. quo casu patriis procul actus ab oris
msItem.note: In Omnia Opera Bapt. Mantuani Carmelitae, Bologna 1502; Ecloga IX, fol.xxiv–xxivv.

msItem.title: Inscription
msItem.rubric: In Lusitania hispaniarum Provincia supra quendam pontem.
msItem.note: C.I.L. II. 761

msItem.incipit: Heu ne quis rebus ponat sua uota secundis
msItem.note: For Count Girolamo Riario, assassinated April 14 1488. Apparently another version of Tebaldeo's ‘De Morte comitis Hieronymi’; see Pasquazi, Rinascimento Ferrarese cit., pp.35, 110, 115.

msItem.incipit: Dü: precor ut fesse puppi fessoque regenti
Iam tandem rapido fugit mea pinus ab aestu
Arcanum fragili charte committere quicquam
Quae sub sole iacet gens, in tres diuidat omnes
Defecit medio cursu, puer Icarus audax
Tota tibi studiose dies, nec inutile tempus
Sextus Hilasque suis complerant omnia furtis
Marmore in hoc recubans, nihil esse a morte philelphus
Ecce fauentinas it pugnaturus ad arces
Quod tantus sacram fuerit concursus in aedem
Haec dies: haec est veneranda cunctis
Queritis oraret pleno dum Galbula circo
Me verona tulit: paphi mihi mite dederunt
Diua regnatrix Generosa poli
Mendaces, stultos, indoctaque pectora uita
Pauperibus: miserisque dari sua prandia primus
Coelicolas aluis precibus sine fine fatiget
Colla niues superant: aurum: coma: marmora pectus

msItem.rubric: An. Volscus. Ad Innoc. VIIJ. Summum Pontificem
msItem.incipit: Res romana perit, Iam dudum maxime regum
Insubres populi flere licet: dies
msItem.note: On the death of Galeazzo Maria Sforza in 1476

msItem.title: Epitaphium hominum sceleratissimi
msItem.incipit: Heu hic est sceleratissimus omnium
Lascivi procul hinc pueri: procul este puellȩ
Et Phoebum et Musas, et Cirrham, et Laurea serta

msItem.rubric: Epigramma sine auctoris nomine Repertum Romae in Palatio apostolico
msItem.incipit: Pulsa diu terris et inani nomine virtus
Vulgarem solitus Venerem conducere Myrrho
Caesar ut Hesperio pepulit de Littore magnum
Pompeius post tot bella illustresque triumphos.

msItem.author: ‘Battista Fiera Medicus’
msItem.title: Poems
msItem.note: On the group of poems by Fiera in our MS. see C. Dionisotti in Italia Medioevale e Umanistica I, 1958, pp.403–4; he says this was the dedicatory poem of Fiera's De Coenis

msItem.incipit: Si cui delitias iocosque nostros

msItem.rubric: Ad amicos quoscumque et ad Apollinem
msItem.incipit: Si quis es antiqui pia quem convincat amici
Stet Domus haec donec fluctus formica marinos.
msItem.note: WIC 18621. The cardinal is probably Domenico della Rovere, cr. 1479, d.1501.

msItem.rubric: Tetrasticon A. Politiani in Apollinem et Daphnen.
msItem.incipit: Amplexus uirides frondose virginis artus
msItem.note: A variant of the poem ‘In Daphnem’ on fol.119; pr. del Lungo, op.cit. p.548.

msItem.incipit: Claram sydereo nitore flammam
O, qui flosculus es iuvenculorum
Si pridiana hodie potes esse obsonia mecum
Surripui Calamum: Montes mihi fata minatur

msItem.rubric: [Antonius] Delius Volscus Privernas ad Alphenum Severum
msItem.incipit: Quod decet ingenium nobis Alphene dedisti
msItem.note: pr. Conestabili Mem. di A. Alfanicit., p.101

msItem.rubric: Epigramma pervetustum In templo olim primigenię Fortunae apud Preneste
msItem.note: C.I.L. XIV. 2852

msItem.rubric: B. Fierę Medici . In Inuidum Maledicum redargutio
msItem.incipit: Liuor edax rabido medicum qui dente lacessit

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: A collection of Latin inscriptions mostly from Italy, but with a few from Dalmatia, Germany, France and Spain, in no special order, probably selected from a sylloge of Fra Giocondo's, or one deriving from him, for it includes two inscriptions from Nîmes: C.I.L. XII. 3236 and 4027 and two from Stimigliano, C.I.L. IX, 4792 and 4816 (fols.100–100v, 102v–3) which appear first in his collections. Many of the inscriptions, such as the Arch at Ancona, C.I.L. IX. 5894 (fol.94v), the aqueduct at Athens, C.I.L. III.549 (fol.99) and the false ‘Tabula aerea’ at Padua, C.I.L. V.202* (fol.106v) first appeared in the collections of Ciriaco d'Ancona. On fol.99 C.I.L. VI.20201 is entitled ‘Romae in domo D. Coronati’.

msItem.author: Pontano
msItem.title: De Cola Pisce
msItem.rubric: ‘Pontani Carmen de quodam Cola qui Piscis cognominabatur excerptum ex opere eius’ beg: , ends : . It is ‘’
msItem.incipit: Haec pistrix. Sed quo celi sub sydere natum
msItem.explicit: (fol.111v)In ponto degit vitam: et fatum equore clausit
msItem.note: From Urania, Bk.IV; in his Opera, ed. Basle 1556, Vol.IV, pp.3036–40.

msItem.rubric: Epistola Politiani in laudem Fratris Mariani Genezanensis ordinis heremitarum
msItem.incipit: Angelus Pol. Tristano chalcho suo. S.D. Scribis Marianum Genezanensem theologiae
msItem.explicit: non desideret. Vale xi Kl. Aprilis MCCCCXC.
msItem.note: Pr. in Angeli Politiani Opera, Basle 1553, pp.52–3 but dated MCCCCLXXXIX.

msItem.rubric: F. Fiani de Contemnendis opibus et diligenda paupertate Carmen
msItem.incipit: Ascendat quicumque velit fastigia foelix.
msItem.note: WIC 1566, also in MS.Berlin Hamilton 458, fol.26v: see Mommsen in Jahrb. K. Preuss. Kunstsammlungen 4, 1883, p.81.

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: A collection of Latin inscriptions (and one in Greek, from Delphi, fol. 118) mostly from Italy, in no special order, probably largely deriving from Fra Giocondo. Including:

msItem.rubric: Antiquum Tetrasticon in basi Nimphae cuiusdem dormientis. Nunc in hortulo Cardinalis S. Clementis
msItem.note: C.I.L. VI, 3e*
C.I.L. VI. 1702, repeated correctly on fol.143v as in S. Basilio, Rome
C.I.L. VI. 3m*

msItem.incipit: D.M.S.L. Asconio Elpinchano Sodal. Titi.
Non ager hic oleę, non frugum aut fertilis uuę
msItem.note: First printed by Perosa in Studi in on. U. Paoli cit., p.550, from this MS. See no.2c above

msItem.incipit: Vidit ut hanc liuor faciem: si carpere non est.
msItem.note: Also on fol.3v. First printed by Perosa, loc. cit., from this MS.
pr. del Lungo, op.cit. p.153
pr. del Lungo, p.546

msItem.rubric: Ad hirundinem nidificantem sub Medea statua
msItem.note: pr. del Lungo, p.546
pr. del Lungo, p.547
pr. del Lungo, p.547
pr. del Lungo, p.547
pr. del Lungo, p.547
pr. del Lungo, p.548. See also fol. 88v above.

msItem.rubric: Testamentum militare repertum in antiquiss. lapide
msItem.incipit: K.lis sext.lis L. Manlio et Q. Torquato cons.
msItem.note: Repeated, with variants, on fol.174v

msItem.incipit: Quom ante hos dies Coniugem et filium ammiserim (sic)
msItem.note: ends fol.119v. Rest of page, and fol.120, left blank.
Copied in later by the same scribe.

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: Collection of Latin inscriptions, in two sections, apparently copied at different times.

Inscriptions from Rome. Many of these derive from a late 15th cent. version of the Sylloge Signoriliana. On fol.127: ‘Epigramma in urna repertum et mihi carissimum’ beg: D. M. T. Venoni Feliciani. Some have unusual titles: fol.125 ‘In Sancto petro in vincula Romae. et nunc est in orto Cardinalis S. petri ad vincula apud S. apostoeum’, C.I.L. VI. 1770; fol.131v: ‘In portion domus de meximo’ for C.I.L. VI. 21714 and 22712; fol.127v: ‘Apud domum Alexandri de Schiacijs’ for C.I.L. VI. 471 and fol.128 ‘Apud domum petri de Cosciariis de urbe’ for C.I.L. VI. 2174 appear in Peutinger

Miscellaneous inscriptions including groups from Benevento (fol.135–136v), Capua (fol.138v–140) and Rome (fol. 140v–143v). The Benevento and Capua inscriptions may be selections from a version of Giocondo: they appear in the same order as in his sylloge in MS. Laur. Ashb.905 with a few additions and variants on titles. The Roman collection has debts especially to Giocondo, but individual features, e.g. the title, fol.141v, ‘In domo d. Barth. de Cambiis’, for C.I.L. VI 13351. On fol.143v the title ‘In domo episcopi R. D. Nicolai franchi parentini’ for C.I.L. VI. 8508 dates this collection between 1477–85. On fol.140v is an early appearance of C.I.L. 23210–1 as ‘In nobili viridario R. Cardinalis S. Petri ad Vincula Transtiberim’.

msItem.incipit: Quid iuuat Adriacum consternere classibus aequor?
msItem.note: Probably a version of the poem ‘In Venetos’ found in Tebaldeo's autograph. MSS.Vat.Lat.3389 fol.22 and Estense 681 fol.183 which begins: Quid iuvat Heridani consternere classibus undas. See Pasquazi, Rinascimento Ferrarese cit. pp.111, 118

msItem.rubric: Dum Venetum turme uiuaria lata pererrant
msItem.note: In V.L. 3389 fol.28

msItem.incipit: Sunt qui triste putent omen, quod fulminis ictu.
msItem.note: In V.L.3389 fol.22v

msItem.incipit: Hic feltrense decus memorabilas (sic): gloria pacis.
msItem.note: In V.L. 3389 fol.88v

msItem.rubric: Uxor Magnifici Roberti Ariminensis conqueritur de morte mariti et patris qui eodem die obierunt
msItem.incipit: Lux eadem rapuit patrem: rapuitque maritum.
msItem.note: Pr. Pasquazi, op.cit., pp.155–6 from MS.Ferrara 395. Roberto Malatesta and Federico da Montefeltro, Duke of Urbino, both died in Sept.1482

msItem.incipit: Nox erat et densa coelum sub nube latebat
msItem.note: In V.L.3389 fol.25v

msItem.incipit: Laeta dies tandem nostrae se prebuit urbi
msItem.note: Variants in V.L. 3389 fol.26, quoted by Pasquazi, pp.33–4

msItem.incipit: Olim roma suo rexit moderamine terras
Seu te Nereides liquidis aluere sub undis.
msItem.note: MS.Estense 681, fol.120; V.L. 3389 fol.24v has a different version

msItem.incipit: Quo vigor ille abiit? quo magna potentia? quo nam
Duxisti thusca claros de gente triumphos
Hac iacet armorum ductor Leonellus in urna
msItem.note: Another version, beg: Scire cupis qui sim? apparently in Vat. Lat. 3389 fol.79v

msItem.incipit: Hic tegitur phyllis: casum si queris acerbum
Sepe rogas aliquid mittam tibi Pice legendum
msItem.note: Variants in V.L. 3389 fol.14v, quoted by Pasquazi, pp.32–3

msItem.incipit: Cum tibi sit cunnus: cum sit tibi mentula Marce
Errat et argutos nescit discernore cantus
Candida dum premerem nostris tua colla lacertis
msItem.note: V.L.3389 fol.6v; Estense 681 fol.32v

msItem.incipit: Quotidie logices dubiosa enigmata soluis
Donec eras paruus cerealia dona petebas
msItem.note: Estense 681 fol.28

msItem.incipit: Dum parat impubem praecidere glaucia sestum
msItem.note: Pr. Pasquazi, p.196 from V.L.3389 fol.65

msItem.incipit: Componis satyras: arguta epigrammata condis
msItem.note: V.L.3389 fol.12; Estense 681 fol.24

msItem.incipit: Hoc ego candenti Ludoucicus marmore claudor
Qui fueras tota mendax notissimus urbe
msItem.note: Estense 681 fol.20v

msItem.incipit: Dum tetro fureret clausi Leo carceris antro
msItem.note: Estense 681 fol.20

msItem.incipit: Non rota fortumae: non seua potentia mortis
msItem.note: V.L. 3389 fol.76v; Estense 681 fol.113

msItem.incipit: Dum septena tibi celebrantur culmina Romae
msItem.note: Pr. Pasquazi, pp.153–5, from MS.Ferrara 395, with variants

msItem.rubric: L. Harmonius Puteolanus Magnifico Nestori Maluitio equiti Hyerosclimitano. S.P.D.
msItem.incipit: Meum semper ab ineunte actate
msItem.note: Letter sending Malvezzi the poem which follows

msItem.rubric: Fausti [Andrelini] Poetae Forliuiensis De XIIm articulis fidei: et laudibus poetarum ad diuum Ludouicum Gonzagam Principem Nantuanum. Carmen
msItem.incipit: Nobilis athalico fulget si regia luxu
msItem.note: This poem is also on fol.73–5, where it is correctly dedicated to the Bishop of Mantua Lodouico Gonzaga, or.1483, who was Andrelini's patron. The poem, and the letter preceding it, were first published in Rome on June 19 1484 – see C. Dionisotti ‘Miscellanea Umanistica Transalpina’ in Giorn. Stor. Lett. Ital. 110, 1937, pp.280–1

msItem.rubric: Faustus ad D. Ludouicum Gonzagam Principem Mantuanum
msItem.incipit: Annua versatis mandantur semina sulcis

msItem.author: Antonius Thebaldeus Ferrariensis
msItem.title: Letter
msItem.rubric: Magnanimo ac inuictissimo Ductori Alphonso Aragonio Calabriae Duci
msItem.incipit: Cum superioribus diebus infelicissima Italiae regna
msItem.note: Pasquazi, op.cit., pp.172–3, in note, from MS.Ferrara 395 fol.23v–24

msItem.author: Antonius Thebaldeus Ferrariensis
msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Vnde repentini subito uenere tumultus?
msItem.note: Pr. Pasquasi, op.cit., pp.172–8 from MS. cit. fol.24–26v

msItem.author: Antonius Thebaldeus Ferrariensis
msItem.title: Sonnet
msItem.incipit: Che fai? che pensi? a che stai pigra e lenta?
msItem.note: Pr. Pasquazi pp.177–8, in note, from MS.cit fol.27.

msItem.title: Letter of Giovanni Mocenigo, Doge of Venice, to Pope Sixtus IV ‘Summo Pontifici’
msItem.incipit: Accepimus breue Stis V. ea qua decuit
msItem.note: Pr. F. Longo in Arch. Stor. Ital. Ser.I, Vol.7, Pt.I (1843) pp.272–7, with address and date ‘Venetiis, Idibus Januarii, 1482’

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.incipit: Huc ades et laceros ferraria solue capillos
msItem.note: Ends fol.160: In the autograph Estense MS. of Tebaldeo's poems, fol.142; see Pasquazi, op.cit., p.116.
On leaves originally left blank a number of contemporary additions were made:
By an unknown scribe, fols. 160v-173
Preceded by two dedicatory letters:
to Fernando de Acuña, Viceroy of Sicily [1488–94]
to Alfonso Cherillo, Bishop of Pamplona [1473–91]

msItem.incipit: Desine Lector in hunc ungues armare libellum
msItem.note: Beginning of the first book of poems; a collection of epigrams, several of them addressed to members of Pomponio Leto's Academy in Rome: Agostino Maffei, Parthenius, etc.

msItem.rubric: Tranq. Thamyre Amor Ignitus: Ad Lysam
msItem.incipit: Te cecum: puerum: nudum: plumisque volantem
msItem.note: The second book of poems, all to Lysa. End fol.172v

msItem.incipit: Ut caderet pietas. probitas: Astrea: fidesque
Ne quid in humanis sineret mors improba tutum

msItem.note: By a second unknown scribe, fol.174–175v.

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: Inscriptions from North Italy: Lodi, Ravenna, etc. copied with care, in capitals, and a ‘Testamentum’, already copied on fol.119 where this scribe makes a cross-reference

msItem.rubric: Ex Codice Vergilii peruetusto olim Reseruato in In (sic) Bibliotheca illa celeberrima arcis Ticinensis, quam Diuus Galeaz. mediolan. Dux Magnis sumptibus instaurauerat. In presentia vero apud virum Nobilem Antonium Pyrrhum papiensem conseruatur. Qui quidem Codex olim fuisse dicitur Illustris Poet Francisci Petrarch
msItem.incipit: Laurea propriis virtutibus illustris
msItem.note: Copy, probably not direct, of Petrarch's note on Laura and of others by him, including the 3 distichs for Simone Martini's painting, from the pages added to his Virgil, now MS. Milan Ambros. A.49. See facsimile: Francisci Petrarcae Vergilianus Codex ed. G. Galbiati, Milan, 1930. The MS. came into Antonio Pirro's possession when the Ducal collection was dispersed.

By B. da S. Casciano di Pisa, possibly in Pesaro. A Simone di Ser Bart. da S. Casciano di Pisa was in Pesaro in mid 15th cent., see documents listed in Mazzatinti, Inv. delle Bibl. d'Italia, 35, pp.135–6; 37, p.96.

msItem.incipit: Cineres et ossa Laudaci
msItem.explicit: F.F.F.F.F./ feno. fame. furor. fetore. fortuna./ per me B. de S.cto Cass.o pisar.
msItem.finalRubric: Verius fortasse. Foemina: Forte: Futuens: Fatum: Finiuit. Io. Bonavolius
msItem.note: A fuller version than in C.I.L. VI 43* or X.195*

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: Copies of Latin inscriptions, mostly in capitals, including groups from Nola, Terni, Teanc etc.

By Io. Bonavolius, i.e. the poet Giovanni Buonavoglia or Benevoli of Mantua, secretary to Giovanni Sforza of Pesaro from c.1489, on whom see E. Rostagno in Bibliofilia I, 1899–1900, pp.145 ff. (reproduction of Buonavoglia's hand on p.165) and 186 ff; Luzio-Renier in Giorn. Stor. Lett. Ital. cit. 42, 1903, pp.109–11. He wrote a signed addition on fol.173, see above, and, on fol.173v:

msItem.incipit: Infoelix fatum: Prior debui mori Mater
Hieronymus Savonarola Divi Dominici Flamen non Pius. sed flamma impia
Quis iacet hic? scelus est: Nomen date, foemina? vel vir?
Sola hominis facies inerat: Mens effera: Nunquam.

msItem.note: He also wrote marginal additions on fols.34 and 35.
By a third unknown scribe
msItem.title: Inscriptions

msItem.note: Copy of inscription at Milan, C.I.L. V 5795, with unusual title

Copies of inscriptions from South Italy: Salerno, Puteoli, Naples etc, some of them uncommon, but including a repetition, less full, of the falsified one on fol.173. This scribe also wrote a marginal addition on fol.90v.
By a fourth unknown scribe, or by the same third

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: Further inscriptions from S. Italy, including a recent one on Maria, daughter of King Ferrante I of Naples [d.1460] and two from Pontano's collection: one, C.I.L. X.196*, probably an adaptation by him of an ancient one. See R. Filangiari di Candida ‘Il Tempietto di G. Pontano in Napoli’, Atti Accad. Pontaniana 56, 1926 pp.134–5.

msItem.title: Distich
msItem.incipit: Ex vitio invitium: in flammas ex igne reversa es.
msItem.note: Version of an anonymous epitaph on Pope Alexander VI. See M. Sanuto, Diarii, V, Venice, 1881, col.95. A contemporary addition.
Further additions were made in the course of the 16th century:

msItem.rubric: In nomine domine nostri Iesu Christi Incipiunt epistole Domini P.F.M.P.P.M.D.XL[?]
msItem.incipit: Aurelius S.S.S.P.D./ Superioribus diebus quum Brundisium contulissem
msItem.explicit: Vale V. Idus octobris / Trebatius S.S.S.P.D.

msItem.title: Inscriptions from an arch at Fano erected in honour of Pope Paul III [1534–1549]
msItem.incipit: Il frisio dell'arco /Paulo iii Pont. Max. ob Caesarem ad reliquias Africani belli extinguendas animatum.

msItem.rubric: Fortuna ad paulum iii pont. Max.
msItem.incipit: Aetherei pars magna poli, terrque potestas
msItem.note: Ends fol.185.

msItem.incipit: Hinque (sic) cyreos age diua saltus
msItem.explicit: fol.187v Urbe frequente. /Finis. / Peruenti (sic) ad ecclesiam hec ex trium puerorum ore perueniunt carmina

msItem.title: Inscriptions
msItem.note: from churches in Pesarc, dated between 1514–1539.

msItem.title: Letters
msItem.note: Copies of two letters in Italian: from Francesco Sforza in Vimercato to Giovanni da Tolentino and the Citizens of Cremona, dated Feb.25 1450, with news of the rising in his favour in Milan on the previous day; from Sveva Sforza Countess of Pesaro, in Parma, to the citizens of Pesaro, sending the same news, dated ‘penultimo februarii 1450’

msItem.rubric: sub statua Adonidis et Veneris in reditu M. Antonii Column triumphanti
In tumulo Octaviani Vbaldini Tuberti Cardinalis fratris Isabella Accorambona uxor

supportDesc.support: Paper, watermark fleur-de-lys in circle, cf. Briquet 7312.
supportDesc.extent:
xxx + 201 leaves 320 215
230 90–100
(between fol.1 and 159; varying between fol.160 and 193v)

history.provenance: Perhaps at Pesaro in the early 16th cent. (fols. 173r-v, 175v-179v)

At the front of the MS. are a partial index made by G. B. Vermiglioli of Perugia (fol.VI–XXI) and a letter written by him to D. Pietro de' Principi Odescalchi (fol.XXIII– VII) about the MS., which he says was given to him at Pesaro in 1820 by Conte Giulio Perticari. Vermiglioli states (but wrongly, it seems) that the hand of the first part (fol.2–160) is that of the Perugian humanist Francesco Maturanzio (1443–1518). See also his Scrittori Perugini I, 1828, p.12; II, 1829, p.121.
W. Ashburner , sale at Lucerne, 26–27 August 1938, bought by Hoepli.

recordHist.source: Typescript description by Bodleian Library staff.
